title: 111_hr493
content: The Act titled "Coal Ash Reclamation, Environment, and Safety Act of 2009" sets requirements for surface storage and disposal of covered wastes in impoundments. The Act "Coal Ash Reclamation, Environment, and Safety Act of 2009" mandates the Secretary of the Interior to establish regulations within 180 days for safe storage and disposal of covered wastes in impoundments. These regulations require impoundments to meet design, construction, and maintenance standards similar to those under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. It prohibits the construction or operation of impoundments for covered wastes without complying with the regulations. The Act mandates regulations for safe storage and disposal of covered wastes in impoundments, with requirements similar to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. Violations will be treated as surface coal mining operations. Pre-existing impoundments are subject to limitations unless specified in an order. The Act mandates regulations for safe storage and disposal of covered wastes in impoundments. Pre-existing impoundments are exempt from certain regulations unless specified in an order. The Secretary is required to complete an inventory of all impoundments within 12 months, assessing design, stability, engineering, and risks posed to surface and groundwater. The Secretary must assess impoundments for risks to human and environmental health and issue orders to ensure compliance. A report to Congress on the inventory findings is required within one year. State programs must comply with the regulations of the Act. Under section 503 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977, states can revise their programs to include regulations on impoundments. This does not affect other laws prohibiting impoundment construction. State standards must meet or exceed federal requirements for impoundment regulation. Under section 503 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977, states can revise their programs to include regulations on impoundments. Covered wastes include coal ash, slag, and flue gas desulfurization materials stored in liquid, semi-liquid, or solid form. An impoundment is defined as any dam or embankment used to retain covered wastes. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior.
